natural problem: Every 5 months, Hal has to replace the batteries in his calculator. He changed them the first time in May. In what month will they be changed the 25th time?
natural solution: If the first time was in May, the second time will be 5 months after May, the third time will be $5\cdot2$ months after May, etc. That means the 25th time will be $5\cdot24$ months away. Since the months repeat every 12 months, we look for the remainder when $5\cdot24$ is divided by 12 and add that many months to May.
We notice that $\frac{5\cdot24}{12}=5\cdot2$, so it turns out that $5\cdot24$ is a multiple of 12 and leaves a remainder of 0 when divided by 12.
So the 25th time will be a certain number of years afterward but still in the same month, $\boxed{\text{May}}$.

a_0.formal problem:
This problem involves temporal calculations and is based on the concept of modular arithmetic. However, Isabelle/HOL, as a theorem prover, does not support direct manipulation of temporal concepts like "months". Therefore, it's hard to translate this natural language problem directly into an Isabelle version. Nevertheless, we can define a function that models the problem in a more abstract way.

Here's an attempt to model the problem using modular arithmetic:

consts n :: nat
consts battery_replacement :: "nat => nat"
axiomatization where
battery_replacement_def: "battery_replacement n = (n*5) mod 12"

theorem
assumes h0 : "battery_replacement 25 = battery_replacement 1"
shows  "battery_replacement 1 = 5" 

In this model, we treat the months as numbers from 0 to 11 (for January to December, respectively), and the function 'battery_replacement' calculates the month in which the batteries will be replaced. Then we prove that the 25th replacement occurs in the same month as the first replacement (May, represented by 5).

 If the first time was in May, the second time will be 5 months after May, the third time will be $5\cdot2$ months after May, etc. That means the 25th time will be $5\cdot24$ months away. Since the months repeat every 12 months, we look for the remainder when $5\cdot24$ is divided by 12 and add that many months to May.
 We notice that $\frac{5\cdot24}{12}=5\cdot2$, so it turns out that $5\cdot24$ is a multiple of 12 and leaves a remainder of 0 when divided by 12.

This problem involves temporal calculations and is based on the concept of modular arithmetic. However, Isabelle/HOL, as a theorem prover, does not support direct manipulation of temporal concepts like "months". Therefore, it's hard to translate this natural language problem directly into an Isabelle version. Nevertheless, we can define a function that models the problem in a more abstract way.

consts n :: nat
consts battery_replacement :: "nat => nat"
axiomatization where
battery_replacement_def: "battery_replacement n = (n*5) mod 12"

theorem
assumes h0 : "battery_replacement 25 = battery_replacement 1"
shows  "battery_replacement 1 = 5" 

In this model, we treat the months as numbers from 0 to 11 (for January to December, respectively), and the function 'battery_replacement' calculates the month in which the batteries will be replaced.   show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: You have a device that needs its batteries replaced every 5 months. If the first battery replacement was done in May, in which month will the 25th battery replacement occur? The answer is May.

a_1.formal problem:
This problem is more about calendar calculations and does not translate neatly into a theorem in Isabelle, which is more suited for formal mathematical proofs. However, here is an attempt:

datatype Month = January | February | March | April | May | June | July | August | September | October | November | December

fun next_month :: "Month ⇒ Month"
where
"next_month January = February" |
"next_month February = March" |
"next_month March = April" |
"next_month April = May" |
"next_month May = June" |
"next_month June = July" |
"next_month July = August" |
"next_month August = September" |
"next_month September = October" |
"next_month October = November" |
"next_month November = December" |
"next_month December = January"

fun add_months :: "Month ⇒ nat ⇒ Month"
where 
"add_months m 0 = m" |
"add_months m (Suc n) = add_months (next_month m) n"

theorem
shows  "add_months May 120 = May"

Since the months repeat every 12 months, we look for the remainder when $5\cdot24$ is divided by 12 and add that many months to May.
 We notice that $\frac{5\cdot24}{12}=5\cdot2$, so it turns out that $5\cdot24$ is a multiple of 12 and leaves a remainder of 0 when divided by 12.
 So the 25th time will be a certain number of years afterward but still in the same month, $\boxed{\text{May}}$.
 *)

datatype Month = January | February | March | April | May | June | July | August | September | October | November | December

fun next_month :: "Month ⇒ Month"
where
"next_month January = February" |
"next_month February = March" |
"next_month March = April" |
"next_month April = May" |
"next_month May = June" |
"next_month June = July" |
"next_month July = August" |
"next_month August = September" |
"next_month September = October" |
"next_month October = November" |
"next_month November = December" |
"next_month December = January"

fun add_months :: "Month ⇒ nat ⇒ Month"
where 
"add_months m 0 = m" |
"add_months m (Suc n) = add_months (next_month m) n"

theorem

  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: What will be the month 120 months after May? The final answer is May.

a_2.formal problem:
Since the problem is a calendar-based problem, it is not directly translatable to an Isabelle theorem as Isabelle deals primarily with mathematical logic and formal proofs. However, if we were to represent the problem in terms of a mathematical function, it could be done as follows:

theorem
fixes month :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. month (n + 1) = (month n + 5) mod 12"
and h1 : "month 1 = 5"
shows  "month 25 = 5"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Every 5 months, Hal has to replace the batteries in his calculator. He changed them the first time in May. In what month will they be changed the 25th time? The final Answer is \text{May}
 ### Proof
 If the first time was in May, the second time will be 5 months after May, the third time will be $5\cdot2$ months after May, etc. That means the 25th time will be $5\cdot24$ months away. Since the months repeat every 12 months, we look for the remainder when $5\cdot24$ is divided by 12 and add that many months to May.
 We notice that $\frac{5\cdot24}{12}=5\cdot2$, so it turns out that $5\cdot24$ is a multiple of 12 and leaves a remainder of 0 when divided by 12.
 So the 25th time will be a certain number of years afterward but still in the same month, $\boxed{\text{May}}$.
 *)

Since the problem is a calendar-based problem, it is not directly translatable to an Isabelle theorem as Isabelle deals primarily with mathematical logic and formal proofs. However, if we were to represent the problem in terms of a mathematical function, it could be done as follows:

theorem
fixes month :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. month (n + 1) = (month n + 5) mod 12"
and h1 : "month 1 = 5"
shows  "month 25 = 5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: A calendar has a repeating cycle where every month is assigned a number from 1 to 12. If we start in May (represented by the number 5) and each subsequent month is assigned a number that is 5 more than the previous month's number (with the numbers wrapping around after 12), what is the number assigned to the 25th month? The final answer is 5.

a_3.formal problem:
datatype Month = January | February | March | April | May | June | July | August | September | October | November | December

fun add_months :: "Month \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> Month" where
"add_months January n = (if n mod 12 = 0 then January else add_months February (n-1))" |
"add_months February n = (if n mod 12 = 0 then February else add_months March (n-1))" |
"add_months March n = (if n mod 12 = 0 then March else add_months April (n-1))" |
"add_months April n = (if n mod 12 = 0 then April else add_months May (n-1))" |
"add_months May n = (if n mod 12 = 0 then May else add_months June (n-1))" |
"add_months June n = (if n mod 12 = 0 then June else add_months July (n-1))" |
"add_months July n = (if n mod 12 = 0 then July else add_months August (n-1))" |
"add_months August n = (if n mod 12 = 0 then August else add_months September (n-1))" |
"add_months September n = (if n mod 12 = 0 then September else add_months October (n-1))" |
"add_months October n = (if n mod 12 = 0 then October else add_months November (n-1))" |
"add_months November n = (if n mod 12 = 0 then November else add_months December (n-1))" |
"add_months December n = (if n mod 12 = 0 then December else add_months January (n-1))"

theorem "add_months May (24*5) = May"

end
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Every 5 months, Hal has to replace the batteries in his calculator. He changed them the first time in May. In what month will they be changed the 25th time? The final Answer is \text{May}
 ### Proof
 If the first time was in May, the second time will be 5 months after May, the third time will be $5\cdot2$ months after May, etc. That means the 25th time will be $5\cdot24$ months away. Since the months repeat every 12 months, we look for the remainder when $5\cdot24$ is divided by 12 and add that many months to May.
 We notice that $\frac{5\cdot24}{12}=5\cdot2$, so it turns out that $5\cdot24$ is a multiple of 12 and leaves a remainder of 0 when divided by 12.
 So the 25th time will be a certain number of years afterward but still in the same month, $\boxed{\text{May}}$.
 *)



datatype Month = January | February | March | April | May | June | July | August | September | October | November | December

fun add_months :: "Month \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> Month" where
"add_months January n = (if n mod 12 = 0 then January else add_months February (n-1))" |
"add_months February n = (if n mod 12 = 0 then February else add_months March (n-1))" |
"add_months March n = (if n mod 12 = 0 then March else add_months April (n-1))" |
"add_months April n = (if n mod 12 = 0 then April else add_months May (n-1))" |
"add_months May n = (if n mod 12 = 0 then May else add_months June (n-1))" |
"add_months June n = (if n mod 12 = 0 then June else add_months July (n-1))" |
"add_months July n = (if n mod 12 = 0 then July else add_months August (n-1))" |
"add_months August n = (if n mod 12 = 0 then August else add_months September (n-1))" |
"add_months September n = (if n mod 12 = 0 then September else add_months October (n-1))" |
"add_months October n = (if n mod 12 = 0 then October else add_months November (n-1))" |
"add_months November n = (if n mod 12 = 0 then November else add_months December (n-1))" |
"add_months December n = (if n mod 12 = 0 then December else add_months January (n-1))"

theorem "add_months May (24*5) = May"

end
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: If you start in May and add 24*5 months, which month will you end up in? The final answer is May.

a_6.formal problem:
The problem provided is more of a logical problem than a mathematical one. As such, it doesn't translate directly into a formal theorem in Isabelle, which is a theorem prover for mathematical theorems. However, if we want to formalize it in some way, we might model it as a function that takes the number of times the batteries have been changed and returns the month (represented as a number) in which they will next be changed.

function battery_change_month :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
where
"battery_change_month 1 = 5" |
"battery_change_month n = (battery_change_month (n-1) + 5) mod 12"
by pat_completeness auto

termination battery_change_month
by (relation "Wellfounded.less_than") auto

lemma
shows  "battery_change_month 25 = 5"
